author: Emma O'Brien
title: Asian stocks fall on China growth concerns as oil extends drop
text:
China investors have been disappointed by latest economic indicators showing manufacturing is still in the doldrums. Reuters by Emma O'Brien Asian stocks fell for the first time in four days amid signs of a deepening slowdown in China's economy. Crude declined with copper, while the won strengthened.
The MSCI Asia Pacific Index lost 0.8 per cent at 1:21 p.m. in Tokyo. The Shanghai Composite Index slumped 2.4 per cent, following its worst monthly drop in six years, although regained some of the lost ground when afternoon trading began. U.S. index futures were little changed. Oil retreated 0.6 per cent, with Iran claiming it will be able to bolster crude production a week after sanctions are lifted. Copper dropped 0.4 per cent. South Korea's currency climbed 0.5 per cent as the central bank reported a record current-account surplus.
An official gauge of Chinese manufacturing at the weekend slid to a five-month low, with the final reading on a private gauge Monday contracting more than estimated. Factory indexes for Japan to India and the U.S. will be released and Greek markets are set to resume following a five-week suspension.
"China will have several hard questions asked of it over the week, feeding into concern it's facing a hard landing," Evan Lucas, a markets strategist in Melbourne at IG Ltd., wrote in an e-mail to clients. "We see a slightly negative start to August."
Equities globally rose 0.8 per cent in July as some strong U.S. company earnings and the American economic recovery outweighed the Greek crisis and ructions in China's stock market. The S&P 500 rose 2 per cent, the most since February, while the Stoxx Europe 600 Index added 4 per cent. The Asia Pacific index fell 2.9 per cent, despite gains in Japanese shares.
Asian moves Japan's Topix declined 0.3 per cent, while the Kospi gauge in Seoul dropped 1.2 per cent. The Hang Seng China Enterprises Index of Chinese stocks traded in Hong Kong slid 1.7 per cent, heading for its lowest close in eight months. Taiwan's Taiex index slumped 1.7 per cent.
The Shanghai Composite headed for its lowest level since July 8. The gauge sank 14 per cent last month as traders cut leveraged bets amid concern valuations were unsustainable.

The precious metal slid 6.5 per cent in July, its worst monthly performance since June 2013, as the prospect of higher U.S. interest rates as soon as September dimmed its investment appeal.
Copper for three-month delivery on the London Metal Exchange slipped to $us5,209.00 a metric ton, after reaching $us5,164 last week, its lowest price since July 2009. China is the world's largest consumer of industrial metals.
Looming PMIs China's official manufacturing purchasing managers' index fell to 50 for July, just below the 50.1 median economist estimate and down from 50.2 in June. The Caixin China manufacturing PMI slid to a two-year low . Factory gauges for the euro area and the US are also due Monday.
Canada's dollar led declines against the greenback. Bloomberg's dollar gauge, which tracks the currency against 10 major peers, rose 0.1 per cent. The index climbed 2.3 per cent in July.
Monthly payrolls data due at the end of this week in the U.S. may give further clues about the timeline for a rate increase by the Federal Reserve.
South Korea's won strengthened the most in a month. The excess in the broadest measure of trade was $us12.2 billion in June, the 39th monthly surplus, according to Bank of Korea data released Monday.
West Texas Intermediate crude declined to $us46.85 a barrel after capping its worst month since 2008 in July. Brent slipped 0.6 per cent to $us51.91.
Iranian Oil Minister Bijan Namdar Zanganeh said output could increase by 500,000 barrels a day within a week after international sanctions are eased and by 1 million barrels a day within a month after that, according to the state-run Islamic News Agency. Sanctions against Iran's oil industry should be lifted by late November, he said, according to the Iran oil ministry's Shana news agency.
